https://prez.dev/description.@value: A metamorphic facies is defined by a repeatedly occurring and thus predictable set of stable mineral assemblages in metamorphic rocks. Such metamorphic mineral assemblages crystallize and are stable over a range of externally imposed physical conditions, most crucially lithostatic pressure and temperature, and thus the facies define areas in two-dimensional plots of pressure–temperature space. There is a demonstrable/proven relationship between mineral composition and bulk rock chemical composition and a consistent relationship through geological time. Rocks which contain certain metamorphic mineral assemblages can therefore be linked to particular tectonic settings, times and places in the geological history of an area. The boundaries between facies are typically gradational as the disappearance or appearance of minerals occurs over pressure, temperature, space and time. The vocabulary is based on Fettes and Desmons (2007, Metamorphic Rocks: a classification and glossary of terms — Recommendations of the International Union of Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Metamorphic Rocks edited by D Fettes and J Desmons, 244p.), with further subdivisions for some facies. Definitions also borrow from Neuendorf et al. (2005, Glossary of Geology: 5th edition, revised edited by KKE Neuendorf, JP Mehl Jr and JA Jackson: American Geological Institute, Alexandria, Virginia, USA, 779p.). More detailed metamorphic mineral assemblages for specific rock types can be found at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metamorphic_facies).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Metamorphic facies corresponding to high grade and middle to high P/T values, and bounded (in rocks of suitable composition) by the omphacite–garnet-in reactions. Metabasic rocks are represented by omphacitic pyroxene and almandine–pyrope garnet, and lawsonite in the coolest rocks. Also common, but not essential, is the association pyrope–olivine–diopside–enstatite. At ultra-high pressures (minimum 28kbar at 600°C), coesite, diamond or majoritic garnet occur in metabasic rocks. Metapelitic rocks are not typically reported as having recorded eclogite-facies conditions and therefore diagnostic mineral assemblages are not reported for them. The facies represents the highest pressures possible for metamorphism in Earth's crust and upper mantle. It occurs to higher pressure than the blueschist, amphibolite and granulite facies (approximately >15kbar), and over a broad range of temperatures (approximately >500°C). The facies encompasses low to moderate (geo)thermal gradients and heat flow, and subduction environments are typical for the lower temperature part of the eclogite facies.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Definition adapted from IUGS (2007); Glossary of Geology (5th edition, American Geosciences Institute); Elias and Alderton (2021; Encyclopedia of Geology, 2nd edition, Academic Press); and Vernon and Clarke (2008; Principles of metamorphic petrology / Cambridge University Press. ISBN: 9780521871785. xi, 446p).
